dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, welcome back to the show. We've got a wild one today, straight out of the, uh, courtrooms and onto your airwaves. It involves Tesla, Walmart, andâ€¦ spontaneously combusting solar panels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, welcome back to the show. We've got a wild one today, straight out of the, uh, courtrooms and onto your airwaves. It involves Tesla, Walmart, and spontaneously combusting solar panels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Elon Musk Walmart claims that Tesla installed faulty solar panels that eventually spontaneously combusted and caught fire at seven Walmart stores around the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow. Yeah, I saw this headline. So, Walmart is suing Tesla, but the weirdest part is Tesla's defense, right? Like, Elon Musk is basically saying, "Our panels were *too* good, that's why they caught fire."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, wow. Yeah, I saw this headline. So, Walmart is suing Tesla, but the weirdest part is Tesla's defense, right? Like, Elon Musk is basically saying, Our panels were too good, that's why they caught fire.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tesla did not immediately respond to a request for comment from Forbes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It's wild. In the lawsuit, Tesla actually praises its own inspectors for, like, their "meticulous attention to detail" and says the cable connectors were "highly compatible," ensuring "optimal performance."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It's wild. In the lawsuit, Tesla actually praises its own inspectors for, like, their meticulous attention to detail and says the cable connectors were highly compatible, ensuring optimal performance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The lawsuit alleges that Tesla inspectors didnt notice defects that were visible to the naked eye, used cable connectors that werent compatible with one another and failed to see that loose and hanging wires were present at multiple sites.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] So, he's saying they're so good, they just, uh, burst into flames? Because they were *too* optimal?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, he's saying they're so good, they just, uh, burst into flames? Because they were too optimal?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, well, it's more like they're trying to establish that it wasn't a product defect from their end, if that makes sense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, well, it's more like they're trying to establish that it wasn't a product defect from their end, if that makes sense.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, right. And what about Walmart's side in all this? What are *they* claiming?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, right. And what about Walmart's side in all this? What are they claiming?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Walmart's claiming *their* business model was, like, highly considered for rapid installation, crucial for profit, and that all their contractors and subcontractors were "thoroughly vetted, trained, and supervised."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Walmart's claiming their business model was, like, highly considered for rapid installation, crucial for profit, and that all their contractors and subcontractors were thoroughly vetted, trained, and supervised.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Walmart says in the lawsuit it believes the failures were the result of rushed installation because Teslas solar division adopted an ill-considered business model that required it to install solar panel systems haphazardly and as quickly as possible in order to turn a profit, and the contractors and subcontractors who performed the original installation work had not been properly hired, trained, and supervised.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. So everyone's saying their part of the process was perfect, but somehow these panels still ended up catching fire at seven different stores. It's a head-scratcher.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. So everyone's saying their part of the process was perfect, but somehow these panels still ended up catching fire at seven different stores. It's a head-scratcher.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The lawsuit alleges that Tesla inspectors didnt notice defects that were visible to the naked eye... Tesla did not immediately respond to a request for comment from Forbes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is, B. And this all, you know, ties back to Tesla's big move into solar. Remember the SolarCity acquisition?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is, B. And this all, you know, ties back to Tesla's big move into solar. Remember the SolarCity acquisition?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tesla got into the solar business after it acquired SolarCity in 2016 for $2.6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, the $2.6 billion dollar one back in 2016. That was supposed to make solar their top revenue stream. How's that been going, overall?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, the two point six billion dollar one back in twenty sixteen. That was supposed to make solar their top revenue stream. How's that been going, overall?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tesla got into the solar business after it acquired SolarCity in 2016 for $2.6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, um, the article *does* mention "smooth, predictable sales" for its residential panels, which sounds... good, I guess?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, um, the article does mention smooth, predictable sales for its residential panels, which sounds good, I guess?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But production of its residential solar panels under Tesla has been mired with delays and plunging sales.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] But didn't Elon *just* announce that whole new rental plan for solar systems this week?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But didn't Elon just announce that whole new rental plan for solar systems this week?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Just this week, CEO Elon Musk announced a revamped pricing plan in an effort to boost the slowing business.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Like, starting at fifty bucks a month. Clearly, they felt the need to, y'know, boost the business significantly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Like, starting at fifty bucks a month. Clearly, they felt the need to, y'know, boost the business significantly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The new pricing model allows residents in six states to rent solar power systems starting at $50 a month ($65 a month in California) instead of buying them up front.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, maybe not *as* smooth or predictable as they'd hoped, if they're revamping pricing like that. It's a tough market to crack.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, maybe not as smooth or predictable as they'd hoped, if they're revamping pricing like that. It's a tough market to crack.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. And these lawsuits, uh, they certainly don't help with public perception.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. And these lawsuits, uh, they certainly don't help with public perception.

dialogue_turns.text: Nope. Just another day, another dramatic headline, courtesy of Elon.
